author: Torgeir T. Søvik
studyaim: To determine whether duodenal switch leads to greater weight loss and more favorable improvements in cardiovascular risk factors and quality of life than gastric bypass.
primaryoutcome: Change in BMI after 2 years
secondaryoutcomes: anthropometric measures; concentrations of blood lipids, glucose, insulin, C-reactive protein, and vitamins; and health-related quality of life and adverse events
note: Patients with a body mass index between 50 and 60 kg/m2 were randomly assigned to undergo gastric bypass or duodenal switch; aged 20 to 50 years.

author: Torgeir T. Søvik
studyaim: To determine whether duodenal switch leads to greater weight loss and more favorable improvements in cardiovascular risk factors and quality of life than gastric bypass.
primaryoutcome: Change in BMI after 2 years
secondaryoutcomes: anthropometric measures; concentrations of blood lipids, glucose, insulin, C-reactive protein, and vitamins; and health-related quality of life and adverse events
note: Patients with a body mass index between 50 and 60 kg/m2 were randomly assigned to undergo gastric bypass or duodenal switch; aged 20 to 50 years.

author: Miguel F Herrera
studyaim: To assess the additional effect of sudden visceral fat reduction by omentec- tomy on metabolic syndrome, acute-phase reactants, and inflammatory mediators in patients with grade III obesity (G-III O) undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB)
primaryoutcome: Components of metabolic syndrome: BMI, SBP, DBP,Glucose, Insulin, Total cholesterol, triglycerides and lipoproteins
secondaryoutcomes: Inflammatory mediators(IL6, CRP, leptin, adiponectin)
note: Patients with metabolic syndrome with grade III obesity some with diabetes, dyslipidemia and hypertension.

author: Miguel F Herrera
studyaim: To assess the additional effect of sudden visceral fat reduction by omentec- tomy on metabolic syndrome, acute-phase reactants, and inflammatory mediators in patients with grade III obesity (G-III O) undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB)
primaryoutcome: Components of metabolic syndrome: BMI, SBP, DBP,Glucose, Insulin, Total cholesterol, triglycerides and lipoproteins
secondaryoutcomes: Inflammatory mediators(IL6, CRP, leptin, adiponectin)
note: Patients with metabolic syndrome with grade III obesity some with diabetes, dyslipidemia and hypertension.

author: Oral Ospanov
studyaim: To compare the treatment modalities in terms of changes in BMI and telomere length (as a possible biomarker of life expectan cy) and resolution of MetS components.
primaryoutcome: Change in BMI
secondaryoutcomes: Change in leukocyte telomere length and other MetS components including insulin resistance, dyslipidemia and hypertension
note: Patients with BMI ranging between 35 and 50, with MetS characterised by hypertension, prediabetic with obesity and T2D

author: Oral Ospanov
studyaim: To compare the treatment modalities in terms of changes in BMI and telomere length (as a possible biomarker of life expectan cy) and resolution of MetS components.
primaryoutcome: Change in BMI

author: Carlos A Schiavon
studyaim: To determine the 3-year effects of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) on blood pressure (BP) compared with medical therapy (MT) alone
primaryoutcome: 30% reduction in total number of antihypertensive medications while maintaining BP less than 140/90 mm Hg
secondaryoutcomes: Number of antihypertensive medications, hypertension remission, and BP control according to current guidelines (<130/80 mm Hg)
note: Participants with hypertension receiving at least 2 medications and BMI ranging between 30 and 39.9 kg/m2 aged 18 to 65 years.

author: Carlos A Schiavon
studyaim: To determine the 3-year effects of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) on blood pressure (BP) compared with medical therapy (MT) alone
primaryoutcome: 30% reduction in total number of antihypertensive medications while maintaining BP less than 140/90 mm Hg
secondaryoutcomes: Number of antihypertensive medications, hypertension remission, and BP control according to current guidelines (<130/80 mm Hg)
note: Participants with hypertension receiving at least 2 medications and BMI ranging between 30 and 39.9 kg/m2 aged 18 to 65 years.

author: Moheb S Eskandaros
studyaim: The aim of this study was to perform a comparison of the operative and postoperative outcomes regarding BMI, asso ciated medical conditions, and nutritional status between the standard RYGB (BPL: 50 cm and AL: 150 cm) and long RYGB (BPL: 100 cm and AL: 100 cm) for up to 3 years postoperatively.
primaryoutcome: BMI, % of total weight loss (%TWL)
secondaryoutcomes: effect on diabetes (DM), hypertension (HTN), dyslipidemia, and nutritional statuses
note: Participants with BMI between 40-50 kg/m2 and with hypertension, diabetes and dyslipidemia

author: Moheb S Eskandaros
studyaim: The aim of this study was to perform a comparison of the operative and postoperative outcomes regarding BMI, asso ciated medical conditions, and nutritional status between the standard RYGB (BPL: 50 cm and AL: 150 cm) and long RYGB (BPL: 100 cm and AL: 100 cm) for up to 3 years postoperatively.
primaryoutcome: BMI, % of total weight loss (%TWL)
secondaryoutcomes: effect on diabetes (DM), hypertension (HTN), dyslipidemia, and nutritional statuses
note: Participants with BMI between 40-50 kg/m2 and with hypertension, diabetes and dyslipidemia

author: Carlos Aurelio Schiavon
studyaim: To assess the impact of bariatric surgery on hypertension improvement in patients with obesity.
primaryoutcome: primary end point was reduction of ≥30% of the total number of antihypertensive medications while maintaining systolic and diastolic blood pressure <140 mm Hg and 90 mm Hg, respectively, at 12 months.
secondaryoutcomes: Secondary end points included number of antihypertensive drugs, systolic and blood pressure (offic and 24-hour ABPM), weight and BMI, waist circumference, fasting plasma glucose and glycohemoglobin, homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance index, lipid profil (low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and triglycerides levels), uric acid, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein levels, interventricular septum diastolic thickness, a 10-year Framingham risk score, and adverse events. secondary end points defined post hoc: remission of hypertension (defined as systolic and diastolic blood pressure <140 mm Hg and 90 mm Hg, respectively, with out medications based on office blood pressure), remission of hypertension (defined as systolic and diastolic blood pressure <140 mm Hg and 90 mm Hg, respectively, without medica tions based on 24-hour ABPM), and reduction of ≥30% of the total number of antihypertensive medications while maintain ing an office systolic blood pressure <120 mm Hg (SPRINT lev els [Systolic Blood Pressure Intervention Trial]) at 12 months.
note: Patients btw 18-65 years with hypertension; BMI between 30-39.9 and taking at least 2 antihypertensive medication

author: Carlos Aurelio Schiavon
studyaim: To assess the impact of bariatric surgery on hypertension improvement in patients with obesity.
primaryoutcome: primary end point was reduction of ≥30% of the total number of antihypertensive medications while maintaining systolic and diastolic blood pressure <140 mm Hg and 90 mm Hg, respectively, at 12 months.
secondaryoutcomes: Secondary end points included number of antihypertensive drugs, systolic and blood pressure (offic and 24-hour ABPM), weight and BMI, waist circumference, fasting plasma glucose and glycohemoglobin, homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance index, lipid profil (low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and triglycerides levels), uric acid, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein levels, interventricular septum diastolic thickness, a 10-year Framingham risk score, and adverse events. secondary end points defined post hoc: remission of hypertension (defined as systolic and diastolic blood pressure <140 mm Hg and 90 mm Hg, respectively, with out medications based on office blood pressure), remission of hypertension (defined as systolic and diastolic blood pressure <140 mm Hg and 90 mm Hg, respectively, without medica tions based on 24-hour ABPM), and reduction of ≥30% of the total number of antihypertensive medications while maintain ing an office systolic blood pressure <120 mm Hg (SPRINT lev els [Systolic Blood Pressure Intervention Trial]) at 12 months.
note: Patients btw 18-65 years with hypertension; BMI between 30-39.9 and taking at least 2 antihypertensive medication

author: Ville Wallenius
studyaim: To compare diabetes remission rates (glycosylated hemoglobin  6.0%, without diabetes medications) in obese T2D patients (body mass index, 35–50) undergoing RYGB or SG.
primaryoutcome: Remission of T2D within 1 year
secondaryoutcomes: 30-day surgical complication rates, weight loss, measured as reduc tion in BMI units, total weight loss (in kilograms), and per centage excess weight loss, as well as percentage weight loss, resolution of other co-morbidities associated with obesity and T2D.
note: Obese T2D patients with BMI of 35-50 kg/m2

author: Ville Wallenius
studyaim: To compare diabetes remission rates (glycosylated hemoglobin  6.0%, without diabetes medications) in obese T2D patients (body mass index, 35–50) undergoing RYGB or SG.
primaryoutcome: Remission of T2D within 1 year

note: Obese T2D patients with BMI of 35-50 kg/m2

author: Fernando de Barros
studyaim: To compare the early changes in endocrine–metabolic parameters associated with SG and GB, particularly with regard to the early remission of co-morbidities before significant weight loss
primaryoutcome: glycemic control 90 days after surgery
secondaryoutcomes: secondary end points were the EWL90, a fall in HbA1c, systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure ,14 15 (DBP), and lipid profile, and changes in hemoglobin, iron, ferritin, vitamin B12, folic acid, albumin, and uric acid.
note: Grade III morbidly obese participants older than 18 but less than 65 years.

author: Fernando de Barros
studyaim: To compare the early changes in endocrine–metabolic parameters associated with SG and GB, particularly with regard to the early remission of co-morbidities before significant weight loss

author: Alan Robson
studyaim: The study aimed to verify the systemic inflammatory response through the analysis of IGF-1, IL-23, and resistin levels and the lipid profile in severely obese women undergoing surgery for obesity and weight-related diseases.
primaryoutcome: Systemic inflam matory profile 6 months after BS, as characterized by the blood levels of the inflammatory markers IGF-1, IL-23, and resistin
secondaryoutcomes: Any changes in clinical and anthropometric variables
note: Women with severe class III obesity with BMI above 40 and above 35 with comorbidities. the control constituted of those who did not meet the inclusion criteria and had no urgent need for surgery.

author: Alan Robson
studyaim: The study aimed to verify the systemic inflammatory response through the analysis of IGF-1, IL-23, and resistin levels and the lipid profile in severely obese women undergoing surgery for obesity and weight-related diseases.

author: Juan Jesús Tur
studyaim: To examine the effects of a nonsurgical approach, Intensive Life style Intervention (ILI) on the therapy of morbid obesity
primaryoutcome: Change in body weight and body mass index
secondaryoutcomes: Percentage change fast- ing plasma Glucose (FPG), glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c) levels, blood pressure (BP) and levels of fasting lipids obtained at baseline and every 3 months after initiation of the interven- tion.
note: Morbidly obese participants

author: Bartolomé Burguera
studyaim: Aimed at comparing the efficacy of two nonsurgical approaches versus bariatric surgery, on body weight changes and metabolic parameters in morbidly obese patients.
primaryoutcome: Body weight in KGs and Body mass index in kg/m2.
secondaryoutcomes: Percent changes in fasting plasma glucose (FPG), glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c), and blood pressure (BP) and of fasting lipids obtained at baseline and every three months after initi- ation of the intervention
note: Morbidly obese patients were selected to participate in the study BMI greater than 40 kg/m2.

author: Robert Caiazzo
studyaim: The aim of this study was to compare the efficacy and safety of 12-month implantation of a duodeno-jejunal bypass liner (DJBL) with conventional medical care in patients with metabolic syndrome (MS).
primaryoutcome: primary aim was to evaluate the efficacy of DJBL in reducing MS prevalence at 1 year after implantation. Rate of resolution of MS.
secondaryoutcomes: included body weight, glucose control (HbA1c and fasting blood glucose), blood pressure, lipids (plasma choles- terol, triglycerides).
note: The participants had obesity, BMI greater than 30 kg/m2 and diagnosed with metabolic syndrome.

author: Robert Caiazzo
studyaim: The aim of this study was to compare the efficacy and safety of 12-month implantation of a duodeno-jejunal bypass liner (DJBL) with conventional medical care in patients with metabolic syndrome (MS).

author: Shelby Sullivan
studyaim: To evaluate safety and efficacy of the poseTM procedure for obesity treatment.
primaryoutcome: Total body weight loss
secondaryoutcomes: Comorbidities resolution, triglycerides
note: Patients with class I and II obesity, aged between 22 and 6o years

author: Shelby Sullivan
studyaim: To evaluate safety and efficacy of the poseTM procedure for obesity treatment.

author: Donald C Simonson
studyaim: This study examined resolution of hyperglycemia (A1C ,6.5% and fasting glucose ,126 mg/dL) 3 years after randomization to either a laparoscopic adjustable gastric band (LAGB) or 1-year diabetes and weight management (DWM) program.
primaryoutcome: To attain normoglycemia, defined as fasting plasma glucose ,126 mg/dL and A1C ,6.5% at 1 year whether or not pharmacologic treatment was used
secondaryoutcomes: Patient reported outcomes e.g quality of life.
note: The study participants had T2D for more than 1 year, aged between 21 and 65 years with a BMI between 30 and 45.

author: Donald C Simonson
studyaim: This study examined resolution of hyperglycemia (A1C ,6.5% and fasting glucose ,126 mg/dL) 3 years after randomization to either a laparoscopic adjustable gastric band (LAGB) or 1-year diabetes and weight management (DWM) program.
primaryoutcome: To attain normoglycemia, defined as fasting plasma glucose ,126 mg/dL and A1C ,6.5% at 1 year whether or not pharmacologic treatment was used
secondaryoutcomes: Patient reported outcomes e.g quality of life.
note: The study participants had T2D for more than 1 year, aged between 21 and 65 years with a BMI between 30 and 45.

author: Boerboom Abel
studyaim: To evaluate the effect of a long biliopancreatic limb RYGB (LBP-GB) and standard RYGB (S-GB) as revisional procedure after laparoscopic adjustable gastric band
primaryoutcome: %TBWL over a period of 4 years
secondaryoutcomes: Reduction of obesity related co-morbidities (type 2 diabetes [T2D], hypertension [HT], and dyslipi- demia [DL]), perioperative complications, and quality of life (QoL)
note: These are participants who had previously undergone LAGB, however they were deemed failed since they did not achieve much weightless and thus recommended revisional RYGB. They have T2D,Hyperlipidemia and hypertension.

author: Boerboom Abel
studyaim: To evaluate the effect of a long biliopancreatic limb RYGB (LBP-GB) and standard RYGB (S-GB) as revisional procedure after laparoscopic adjustable gastric band

author: Sayeed Ikramuddin
studyaim: To compare Roux-en-Y gastric bypass with lifestyle and intensive medi cal management to achieve control of comorbid risk factors.
primaryoutcome: An HbA1c of less than 7.0%, an LDL cholesterol level of less than 100 mg/dL (to convert to millimoles per liter, multiply by 0.0259), and systolic blood pressure less than 130 mm Hg, at the 12-month visit.
secondaryoutcomes: weight loss, adverse events, fasting glucose, HbA1c levels less than 6.0%, high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol and triglycerides levels, diastolic blood pressure, waist circum ference, and medications.
note: Participants had BMI between 30 and 39 and diagnosed with Diabetes at least for six months

author: Sayeed Ikramuddin

author: Liviu Iosif
studyaim: To examine the impact of weight loss on oxidant-antioxidant profile in obese T2D patients
primaryoutcome: Glycated haemoglobin levels HbA1c < 6%
secondaryoutcomes: Oxidative stress markers including adiponectin and leptin
note: Obese male participants aged 30-65 years of age, BMI greater than 30 kg/m2 with T2D between 1 to 15 years.

author: Liviu Iosif
studyaim: To examine the impact of weight loss on oxidant-antioxidant profile in obese T2D patients

secondaryoutcomes: Oxidative stress markers including adiponectin and leptin
note: Obese male participants aged 30-65 years of age, BMI greater than 30 kg/m2 with T2D between 1 to 15 years.

author: Liang Ziwen
studyaim: Comparing the efficacy of RYGB with usual medical care and Exenatide therapy in obese T2DM with hyperten
primaryoutcome: Change in cardiac function in patients undergoing RYGB surgery, usual care or GLP-1 therapy
secondaryoutcomes: secondary aims were to assess changes in metabolic parameters (BMI, HbA1c, HOMA-IR and lipids) and inflammation (hs-CRP, TNF-a, HMW-adiponectin) after a 12- month treatment period.
note: Obese people with T2DM and hypertension, BMI must be greater than 28 kg/m2 and lived with hypertension between 5 -10 years.

author: Florencia Halperin
studyaim: To test the feasibility of methods to conduct a larger multisite trial to determine the long-term effect of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery compared with an intensive diabetes medical and weight management (Weight Achievement and Intensive Treatment [Why WAIT]) program for type 2 diabetes.
primaryoutcome: To attain glycemic control and HbA1c below 6.5%) at 1 year of follow-up.
secondaryoutcomes: Measures of cardiometabolic health, and patient-reported outcomes
note: Participants are persons aged between 21 and 65 years of age diagnosed with T2D more than 1 year before the study. BMI (30 to 42). All participants were receiving antihyperglycemic medications.
